text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Sweden is voted into the United Nations Security Council with a wide margin. Prime Minister Goran Persson says it is a boost for Sweden and its international relations.
- State-owned iron ore mining firm LKAB is moving further underground at its operations at Kiruna in the north. The mine is to be dug one km lower at a cost of 2.5 billion crowns.
- A large tranche of shares worth up to 140 million crowns in Swedish chemicals and plastics company Perstorp are up for sale but the market believes it will be hard to find a buyer.
- Sweden voted into the United Nations Security Council with an overwhelming majority with Portugal also voted in.
- Saab Automobile in Trollhattan has drawn up plans to develop a third model series even though its second series, the new 9000, will not be presented until spring next year.
- British TI group says it will not raise its bid for Swedish polymer group Forsheda from current levels.
- Peter Wallenberg on a 10-day visit to South Africa denies rumours of a possible merger between S-E-Banken and Handelsbanken.
- Taxes on rented houses are set to increase by 22 percent next year.

- A survey by consultancy company KMPG says Sweden has become more attractive to foreign investors, ranking Sweden as fifth in European countries that have sold most companies to foreign investors in 1996, worth a total of nine billion crown.
- Pharmacia & Upjohn is searching for a partner for its biotechnical company Pharmacia Biotech.
